{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient is presenting with persistent epigastric pain that worsens after eating, which is suggestive of a peptic ulcer disease. The presence of multiple duodenal ulcers on upper gastrointestinal endoscopy further supports this diagnosis. The patient's family history of similar symptoms also raises suspicion for an inherited condition. The elevated serum calcium level of 13.2 mg/dL is concerning for hypercalcemia, which can be seen in MEN1 (multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1). MEN1 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the development of tumors in multiple endocrine organs, including the pancreas. These tumors can secrete various hormones, such as gastrin, leading to the development of peptic ulcers. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this patient is MEN1.", "answer_choice": "D"}
